#Text=Buck English
#Text=Buck English was an American Old West outlaw , and one of Lake County , California 's most notorious thieves and stagecoach robbers toward the end of the 19th century . [ 1 ]
#Text=Early life
#Text=Born Lawrence Buchanen English , he soon received the nickname " Buck . "
#Text=The English family feuded with the Durbin family for years , which led to three of Buck 's brothers dying .
#Text=When Buck was thirteen , he became obligated to take revenge on the Durbin family .
#Text=Unlike Black Bart , Lake County 's other notorious thief , Buck was rash and openly flaunted his overconfident capacity .
#Text=He was only 22 years old when he and a companion held up the Lower Lake stage coach and took the Wells Fargo strongbox from the driver .
#Text=Instead of the usual gold or silver for the miners , the box yielded only two brass castings .

#Text=The local newspaper later said , " Shortly before this robbery , he and his companion met four Chinese miners coming down from the Great Western Mine ( near Middletown ) , and robbed them of their watches and money . "
#Text=Territory
#Text=Wells Fargo strongboxes were often the target of stagecoach robbers in Middletown .
#Text=After the mid-19th century , the payroll money was brought in on the stagecoach with an armed guard beside the driver .
#Text=Not all of the holdups in the area were the doing of Buck and his gang , although he was a scourge to the local vicinity for a number of years .
#Text=Buck worked the road near Mountain Hill House , south of Middletown , or near the double bridge north of Middletown near Lower Lake .
#Text=For 20 years , Buck roamed the countryside , making little effort to hide his identity or his disreputable enterprise .
#Text=Duel
#Text=Buck walked the streets of Middletown with a six-shooter strapped to his side , daring any who insulted his authority to a contest .
#Text=One day , he ran into Captain Good on the main street , and harsh words were exchanged .
#Text=Later in the day , they met again , and this time it was a shooting affair , with Buck emerging unscathed .
#Text=The captain was seriously wounded in the arm and legs .
#Text=In another unrelated incident , Buck shot and killed a man in the Middletown skating rink , turning the arena into a scene of pandemonium .
#Text=After jail time
#Text=After his release from San Quentin in 1882 , Buck returned to Middletown .
#Text=Soon after his arrival , the Lebree store in town was robbed of some watches and jewelry .
#Text=Buck left Middletown for a few years , but upon his return , he showed he had not changed .
#Text=It was not long before he held up the stage at the foot of Mount Saint Helena , near the summer home of the mayor of San Francisco .
#Text=The six passengers were ordered out of the stage , and stripped of their possessions .
#Text=Buck made no effort to hide his identity .
#Text=He greeted the driver of a passing wagon , who quickly drove on when he realized a robbery was in progress .
#Text=Capture
#Text=This occurred on May 7 , 1895 .
#Text=A posse was formed and they set off to capture Buck .
#Text=They discovered him on a stagecoach going from Monticello to Napa , and a wild chase ensued .
#Text=The San Francisco Examiner reported the next day :
#Text=One of the robbers jumped to the horses ahead and leveled his guns .
#Text=He waved weapons and spouted profanity , all the while threatening to ' blow ' the driver off of the seat .
#Text=The two robbers were armed with old style Colt revolvers , and he cursed at everyone , especially the Chinamen
#Text=The capture of Buck by Sheriff Bell reads like a Wild West novel .
#Text=He was so badly wounded and had lost so much blood that many thought he would not survive .
#Text=He did recover , however , and returned to San Quentin to serve yet another sentence .
#Text=Buck was not as well known as Black Bart and other Western gunmen of the time , but he created fear wherever he went .

#Text=Although he was arrested for his robberies and attacks on the general population , Buck had his hands in many other criminal activities , including cattle rustling , but he was never brought to justice for any of these crimes .
#Text=Later life
#Text=Buck ended up living long enough to enjoy freedom again after his release from prison .
#Text=He eventually died in 1915 of natural causes , unlike his brothers , all of whom all died violent deaths .
